titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Tony Martin Papers, 1960-2018 MSS.190
titlestmt.author: YZ Chin, 2008-2009.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-11-30 11:13:42 -0500.

change.item: Updated by Jacqueline Rider to reflect incorporation of video preservation master and sub-master files.
Updated by Rachel Searcy to reflect 2019 accretion

did.unittitle: Tony Martin Papers

physdesc.extent: in 3 record cartons, 1 half manuscript box, 1 small flat box, and 1 oversize flat box.

did.abstract: The Tony Martin Papers document Martin's career as a multimedia artist. Martin was one of the first artists to use light as an artistic medium. A recipient of a National Endowment for the Arts Individual Artist Fellowship, Martin has worked regularly with such composers as Pauline Oliveros, Morton Subotnick and David Tudor. The Papers include correspondence, sketches, announcements and other documents pertaining to Martin's artistic production and exhibitions. They also include video and film that was used in Martin's artworks, as well as video documentation of performances.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Tony Martin Papers were donated to Fales Library by Tony Martin in 2006. Two accretions were added to Series I, Subseries A in December of 2015 and October 2019. The accessions associated with these additions are 2015.190 and 2019.056.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This collection is protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use materials in the collection in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. For other uses you need to obtain permission from the rights-holder(s).

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Tony Martin was born in Knoxville, Tennessee in 1937. He studied at the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor and The Art Institute of Chicago. A painter from the outset, Martin is one of the first artists to use light as a medium, often incorporating light compositions and visual projections into musical performances and interactive installations. He is a recipient of a National Endowment for the Arts Individual Artist Fellowship, and has worked regularly with such composers as Pauline Oliveros, Morton Subotnick and David Tudor.

Martin makes works that engage the viewer as a participant. This interest in interactivity began in 1962 with his first multisensory environmental piece, "Theater For Walkers, Talkers, Touchers" (1962); this work, as well as current works, apply principles of resonance and feedback through photo and proximity electronics. Martin has collaborated with David Tudor for the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, created work for the E.A.T. Pepsi Pavilion at Expo 70, in Osaka, Japan, and has exhibited his work at galleries and museums worldwide.
In 1993, Martin helped co-found The Painting Center, with the aim of providing exhibition space to both emerging and mature painters pursuing various formal directions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Tony Martin Papers consist of five series, including one oversize series.

SERIES I: Documentary and Graphic Material is subdivided into five subseries documenting different aspects of Tony Martin's artistic career, as well as his corresondence with notable artists and art organizations. Material in Subseries A through C is arranged chronologically, while material in Subseries D and E is arranged alphabetically.

Subseries A: Exhibitions
Subseries B: Visual Compositons, Performance
Subseries C: Interactive Sculptures
Subseries D: Sketches, Notes and Miscellaneous
Subseries E: Correspondence

SERIES II: Book Collection is housed in the Fales Library. The books have been catalogued in Bobcat. A keyword or related name search with the name "Tony Martin" will retrieve the records for the books. See "separated materials" for a list of the books.
SERIES III: Video Recordings and Motion Picture Film is divided into two subseries:

Subseries A: Video Recordings
Subseries B: Motion Picture Film
SERIES IV: Objects contains electronic circuitry used in Martin's interactive sculptures.
OVERSIZE SERIES contains oversize documentary and graphic material. Some entries are cross-listed with entries in Series I.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Selected printed materials have been removed and individually catalogued in the Downtown Collection. Records for these items can be retrieved through Bobcat.
Chadabe, Joel. Electric Sound: The Past and Promise of Electronic Music. New Jersey: Prentice-Hall, Inc., 1997.
Kluver, Billy, et al., Ed. Pavilion: by Experiments in Art and Technology. New York: E.P. Dutton & Co., Inc., 1972.
Renen, Sheldon. An Introduction to the American Underground Film. New York: E.P. Dutton & Co., Inc., 1967.
Sandford, Mariellen R., Ed. Happenings and Other Acts. London: Routledge, 1995.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date (if known); The Tony Martin Papers; MSS 190; box number; folder number; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University Libraries.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Access copies for some materials are available by appointment for reading room viewing and listening only. Please contact fales.library@nyu.edu, 212-998-2596.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Decisions regarding the arrangement, description, and physical interventions taken on this collection prior to 2019 have not yet been recorded. In 2019, an accretion of an exhibition catalog was rehoused in an archival folder and box, and intellectually incorporated into Series I. Subseries A.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged into four series, some of which are further arranged into subseries.

Series I. Documentary and Graphic Material
Series II. Book Collection
Series III. Video Recordings and Motion Picture Film
Series IV. Objects

did.unittitle: Series I: Documentary and Graphic Material

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains invitations, announcements, catalogues and other material relating to Tony Martin's one-person and group painting exhibitions. The material is arranged chronologically.

Subseries B: Visual Compositions, Performances & Lectures

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mostly made up of announcements and posters advertising Tony Martin's innovative lighting- and music-integrated performances. The subseries also contains some slides, drawings and negatives pertaining to the visual compositions. The material is arranged chronologically.

Subseries C: Interactive Sculptures

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists mostly of announcements and photographs pertaining to Tony Martin's interactive sculptures. Abundant sketches and notes (including schematics) relating to material in Subseries C may be found in Subseries D, under "Interactive Sculptures," "New Media Works…" and the individual names of the installations.

Subseries D: Sketches, Notes & Miscellaneous

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains rich material relating to Subseries C: Interactive Sculptures, including handwritten notes, sketches and schematics of electronic circuits. Other material includes contact sheets as well as press clippings pertaining to Tony Martin's works. Subseries D is arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.p: Consists mainly of Tony Martin's letter and e-mail correspondence with notable artists and art organizations. Subseries E is arranged alphabetically by two main groups, individuals and institutions.

did.unittitle: SF Tape Music Center Revisited
Subseries B: Motion Picture Film

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Consists of Tony Martin's visual compositions, mostly in collaboration with other artists, along with paper documentation regarding some of the works. Paper documents stored within film cans have been removed, foldered, and given the same ID number as the corresponding film element but with a letter B at end of ID number. (Ex. Film: 190.0001A, Folder 190.0001B.)

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Film materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers.

did.unittitle: Tarot
Tarot - Artist's Descriptive Notes
Desert Ambulance; silent; 1963
"Play 4" Film I; all illumination for Morton Subotnick
"Play 4" Film I - Artist's Descriptive Notes
"Play 4" Film II; all illumination for Morton Subotnick
"Play 4" Film II - Artist's Descriptive Notes
Series IV: Objects
Electronic Circuitry for regulating intensity and off/on of light apparatus using frequency discrete photo cells, applied in "The Well" and "Light Pendulum"

odd.head: General
odd.p: Box contains folder with description of object written by Tony Martin.

did.unittitle: OVERSIZE: Series I: Documentary and Graphic Material

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains oversize documentary and graphic material. Some entries are cross-listed with entries in Series I.

did.unittitle: Subseries A: Exhibitions
Galaxy - James Madison University, Sawhill Gallery, Harrisburg, VA ***see also*** Series I, Subseries A, Box I, Folder 40
The Inaugural Show - The Painting Center, New York, NY
Subseries B: Visual Compositions, Performances & Lectures
Original multi-projector light shows for groups including: The Jefferson Airplane, The Great Society, and more - Bill Graham's Fillmore West, San Francisco, CA
Silver Apples of the Moon (Morton Subotnick)

Vector Image Wall and works on paper: Continuously changing electronic drawing (electronic system and video projection) - Institute for Art & Urban Resources, P.S. 1, Long Island City, NY ***see also*** Series I, Subseries C, Box 1, Folder 62
San Francisco Tape Music Center Retrospective: Works of 1963-66 - Victoria Theater, San Francisco, CA
Subseries C: Interactive Sculptures

Interaction Room (or Game Room) (20 x 20 x 10 room containing light and projection installation activated by viewers using game principles) - Howard Wise Gallery, New York, NY ***see also*** Series I, Subseries C, Box 1, Folder 76
Press: San Francisco Bay Guardian
Subseries D: Sketches, Notes & Miscellaneous
Sketches, Drawings for Pieces ***see also*** Series I, Subseries D, Box 1, Folder 93
